messageBody:
I say that all us wrong speaking people should stand up and demand that
the international community immediately recognise the existence and
independence of our grand nation of Sloven!
P.S.
Don't forget to vote amd64 for president!

On a serious note - I think that if there ever was an 'official' QS
dictionary it would have to have 'ideal' en_GB, en_US, en_CA and en_AU
(probably a few more) spellings for every word, otherwise it would be
equally impossible for every one to use (except perhaps the
editor/publisher/author).

Paige Gabhart wrote:
>
> I certainly meant no injury to the Slovenes (and I find no reference to
> them in the etymology of "slovenly.")
>
> Perhaps, "slovenly" was not the correct word to use as it is obvious
> that fast speech requires some change in pronunciation from words spoken
> in isolation. My point was that we should not spell words in QS in
> accordance with the actual sounds produced in fast speech as this would
> be likely to change what people believe to be the proper form of the
> word when it is spoken in isolation.
>
> Also there is a distinction between the normal and expected changes in
> words spoken in isolation compared to fast speech and a person who
> speaks poorly and fails to enunciate properly even by "fast speech"
> standards. That person's speech I would consider "slovenly."
>
> Paige
>
> Benct Philip Jonsson wrote:
>
> >
> > It is unfair to normal fast speech -- not to mention the
> > Slovenes :-) -- to use such wording. From a phoneticians
> > point of view fast-speech reductions are not only completely
> > natural, but also necessary to achieve fast speech at all.
> > Compare how someone...who...has...difficulty...articulating
> > is usually depicted by actors! A person who enunciated
> > maximally 'clear' all the time in normal conversation would
> > be quite irritating for sure.
> >
> > This said the principle to base the spelling of words on how
> > they are enunciated in isolation is a good one, since else
> > the spelling of words would have to vary not only according
> > to whose dialect it represented, but also according to how
> > fast they were supposed to speak, since of course both the
> > amount and patterns of reduction increases the faster we
> > speak. Speakers actually have a mental image of how words
> > are ideally enunciated, e.g. as when reading a word list,
> > which they employ as a standard of comparison when
> > interpreting actual speech at various speeds, even though
> > they seldom actually use that ideal pronunciation, and it
> > has always been that ideal pronunciation people have tried
> > to represent in writing.
> >
> > In short it would be as inefficient to always enunciate
> > maximally 'clear' in speech, as to represent normal fast
> > speech in writing, and there is no reason for bad-
> > mouthing either.
> > --
> >
> > /BP 8^)>
> > --
> > Benct Philip Jonsson -- melroch at melroch dot se
> >
> > a shprakh iz a dialekt mit an armey un flot
> >
> > (Max Weinreich)
> >
> >
>
>
